Recommendation Steps/Approach: EBS snapshots should not be publicly restorable: 1. Check the permissions of EBS snapshots in the console. 2. Ensure snapshots are not shared publicly. 3. Modify the permissions to restrict public access if necessary. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ebs-modifying-snapshot.html

title: EBS
control_title: EBS volume encryption at rest should be enabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach: EBS volume encryption at rest should be enabled: 1. Go to the EC2 console and select "Volumes." 2. Ensure that all volumes have encryption enabled. 3. For volumes without encryption, create encrypted copies. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/EBSEncryption.html

title: EBS
control_title: EBS volumes should be in a backup plan
Recommendation Steps/Approach: EBS volumes should be in a backup plan: 1. Review the backup plans set in your AWS account. 2. Ensure that all EBS volumes are included in a defined backup plan. 3. Create or modify backup plans as necessary. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/aws-backup/latest/devguide/whatisbackup.html

title: EBS
control_title: EBS volumes should be protected by a backup plan
Recommendation Steps/Approach: EBS volumes should be protected by a backup plan: 1. Verify that all EBS volumes are included in an active backup plan. 2. Check backup schedules and retention policies. 3. Implement backup protection where necessary. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/aws-backup/latest/devguide/whatisbackup.html

title: EBS
control_title: EBS volume snapshots should exist
Recommendation Steps/Approach: EBS volume snapshots should exist: 1. Ensure that each EBS volume has at least one snapshot created. 2. Schedule regular snapshots to ensure data recovery capabilities. 3. Monitor the snapshot lifecycle and retention. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ebs-creating-snapshot.html

title: EBS
control_title: EBS volumes should be attached to EC2 instances
Recommendation Steps/Approach: EBS volumes should be attached to EC2 instances: 1. Review all EBS volumes in the EC2 console. 2. Ensure that each volume is attached to an EC2 instance for use. 3. Detach and reattach volumes as needed based on the instance configuration. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ebs-attaching-volume.html

title: EC2
control_title: Ensure Images (AMI's) are encrypted
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure AMIs are encrypted. Steps: 1. Review existing AMIs. 2. Create new encrypted AMIs for any unencrypted images. # REF: Encrypting Amazon Machine Images https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/AMIs.html#creating-an-ami

title: EC2
control_title: Ensure Images (AMI) are not older than 90 days
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure AMIs are not older than 90 days. Steps: 1. Review AMI list. 2. Deregister AMIs older than 90 days. # REF: Deregistering AMIs / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/AMIs.html#deregistering-amazon-machine-images

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 AMIs should restrict public access
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure AMIs restrict public access. Steps: 1. Review AMI permissions. 2. Modify permissions to restrict access. # REF: AMI Permissions /https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/AMIs.html#modify-ami-permissions

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 Client VPN endpoints should have client connection logging enabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure Client VPN endpoints have logging enabled. Steps: 1. Review Client VPN settings. 2. Enable connection logging if not already enabled. # REF: Client VPN Logging / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpn/latest/clientvpn-admin/client-connection-logs.html

title: EC2
control_title: EBS default encryption should be enabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure EBS volumes are encrypted by default. Steps: 1. Review EBS settings. 2. Enable default encryption for new volumes. # REF: EBS Encryption / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/EBSEncryption.html

title: EC2
control_title: Ensure EBS volumes attached to an EC2 instance is marked for deletion upon instance termination
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure EBS volumes are set to delete on termination. Steps: 1. Review EBS attachment settings. 2. Enable delete on termination for attached volumes. # REF: Deleting EBS Volumes / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ebs-attaching-volume.html#ebs-deleting-volume

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instance detailed monitoring should be enabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure detailed monitoring is enabled for EC2 instances. Steps: 1. Review instance settings. 2. Enable detailed monitoring if not already enabled. # REF: EC2 Detailed Monitoring / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/monitoring-instances.html#monitoring-detailed

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instance should have EBS optimization enabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure EBS optimization is enabled on EC2 instances. Steps: 1. Review EC2 instance settings. 2. Enable EBS optimization if not enabled. # REF: EBS Optimization / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/instance-types.html#EBS-optimized

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instances should have IAM profile attached
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure IAM profiles are attached to EC2 instances. Steps: 1. Review instance IAM settings. 2. Attach IAM profiles if missing. # REF: IAM Roles for EC2 / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_roles_use_switch-role-ec2.html

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instances should be in a VPC
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure EC2 instances are launched in a VPC. Steps: 1. Review instance settings. 2. Migrate any instances not in a VPC. # REF: VPC for EC2 / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/EC2_GetStarted.html#ec2-getstarted-vpc

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instances should not use key pairs in running state
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure key pairs are not used for running EC2 instances. Steps: 1. Review running instances for key pair usage. 2. Replace key pair usage with IAM roles or Session Manager. # REF: AWS Session Manager /  https://docs.aws.amazon.com/systems-manager/latest/userguide/session-manager.html

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instances high level findings should not be there in inspector scans
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure that EC2 instances have no high-level findings in Inspector scans. Steps: 1. Review Inspector scan results. 2. Address any identified high-level vulnerabilities. # REF: Amazon Inspector / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/inspector/latest/userguide/inspector_gettingstarted.html

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instance IAM should not allow pass role and lambda invoke function access.
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure IAM roles attached to EC2 instances do not allow pass role actions. Steps: 1. Review IAM role permissions. 2. Restrict permissions to avoid pass role and Lambda invocation. # REF: IAM Roles

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instance IAM role should not be attached with credentials exposure access
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure IAM roles do not have permissions exposing credentials. Steps: 1. Review IAM role settings. 2. Remove any permissions that could expose credentials. # REF: IAM Best Practices https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/best-practices.html

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instance IAM role should not allow to alter critical s3 permissions configuration
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure IAM roles do not allow alteration of critical S3 permissions. Steps: 1. Review IAM permissions for roles. 2. Restrict permissions to alter S3 policies. # REF: S3 Permissions https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/permissions.html

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instance IAM role should not allow cloud log tampering access
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure IAM roles do not allow access to tamper with CloudWatch logs. Steps: 1. Review IAM permissions for roles. 2. Remove tampering permissions. # REF: CloudWatch Logging https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonCloudWatch/latest/logs/WhatIsCloudWatchLogs.html

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instance IAM role should not allow data destruction access
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure IAM roles do not allow access for data destruction. Steps: 1. Review IAM role permissions. 2. Restrict permissions to prevent data destruction. # REF: IAM Data Protection https://aws.amazon.com/security/data-protection/

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instance IAM role should not allow database management write access
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure IAM roles do not allow write access for database management. Steps: 1. Review IAM role permissions. 2. Limit write permissions to databases as needed. # REF: IAM Role Security https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/best-practices.html

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instance IAM role should not allow defense evasion impact of AWS security services access
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure IAM roles do not allow access to disable AWS security services. Steps: 1. Review IAM permissions. 2. Restrict access to disable security services. # REF: AWS Security Best Practices https://aws.amazon.com/security/security-best-practices/

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instance IAM role should not allow destruction KMS access
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure IAM roles do not allow KMS access for destruction. Steps: 1. Review IAM role permissions. 2. Restrict permissions related to KMS destruction. # REF: AWS KMS Permissions / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/kms/latest/developerguide/overview.html
COST: $0 (KMS access is charged based on usage)

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instance IAM role should not allow destruction RDS access
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure IAM roles do not allow destruction of RDS instances. Steps: 1. Review IAM role permissions. 2. Remove any permissions that allow destruction of RDS. # REF: IAM Role Security/  https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/best-practices.html

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instance IAM role should not allow elastic IP hijacking access.
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure IAM roles do not allow access for elastic IP hijacking. Steps: 1. Review IAM role permissions. 2. Restrict permissions to prevent elastic IP hijacking. # REF: Elastic IPs / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/elastic-ip-addresses-eip.html

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instance IAM role should not allow management level access
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure IAM roles do not allow management level access. Steps: 1. Review IAM role permissions. 2. Limit management permissions as necessary. # REF: IAM Best Practices / https://aws.amazon.com/security/best-practices/

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instance IAM role should not allow new group creation with attached policy access
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure IAM roles do not allow creation of new groups with attached policies. Steps: 1. Review IAM role permissions. 2. Remove permissions for group creation. # REF: IAM Group Management / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_groups.html

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instance IAM role should not allow new role creation with attached policy access
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure IAM roles do not allow creation of new roles with attached policies. Steps: 1. Review IAM role permissions. 2. Restrict permissions for role creation. # REF: IAM Role Management / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_roles.html

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instance IAM role should not allow new user creation with attached policy access
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure IAM roles do not allow creation of new users with attached policies. Steps: 1. Review IAM role permissions. 2. Limit user creation permissions. # REF: IAM User Management / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_users.html

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instance IAM role should not allow oraganization write access
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure IAM roles do not allow write access to AWS Organizations. Steps: 1. Review IAM role permissions. 2. Restrict permissions related to organization writes. # REF: AWS Organizations / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/organizations/latest/userguide/orgs_getting-started.html

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instance IAM role should not allow privilege escalation risk access
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure IAM roles do not allow privilege escalation risks. Steps: 1. Review IAM role permissions. 2. Remove permissions that could allow privilege escalation. # REF: IAM Security Best Practices / https://aws.amazon.com/security/best-practices/

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instance IAM role should not allow security group write access
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure IAM roles do not allow write access to security groups. Steps: 1. Review IAM role permissions. 2. Remove permissions that allow modification of security groups. # REF: IAM Security Groups / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/VPC_SecurityGroups.html

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instance IAM role should not allow write access to resource based policies
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure IAM roles do not allow write access to resource-based policies. Steps: 1. Review IAM role permissions. 2. Restrict permissions for resource-based policies. # REF: Resource-Based Policies / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/access_policies.html#resource-based-policies

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instance IAM role should not allow write permission on critical s3 configuration
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure IAM roles do not allow write permissions on critical S3 configurations. Steps: 1. Review IAM role permissions. 2. Limit permissions related to S3 configurations. # REF: S3 Bucket Policies / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/using-bucket-policies.html

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instance IAM role should not allow write level access
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure IAM roles do not allow general write-level access. Steps: 1. Review IAM role permissions. 2. Restrict write-level access as necessary. # REF: IAM Policy Elements / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/access_policies.html#policies-json

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instances should not be attached to 'launch wizard' security groups
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure that EC2 instances are not attached to 'launch wizard' security groups. Steps: 1. Review instance security group attachments. 2. Detach instances from 'launch wizard' security groups. # REF: Launch Wizard https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/launching-instance.html

title: EC2
control_title: Ensure no AWS EC2 Instances are older than 180 days
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure that EC2 instances are regularly reviewed and terminated if older than 180 days. Steps: 1. List all EC2 instances. 2. Identify instances older than 180 days. 3. Terminate or replace as necessary. # REF: EC2 Instance Lifecycle

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instances should not have a public IP address
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure EC2 instances do not have public IP addresses. Steps: 1. Review EC2 instance settings. 2. Remove public IP assignments from instances. # REF: EC2 Public IP https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/elastic-ip-addresses-eip.html

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instances should not use multiple ENIs
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure EC2 instances do not use multiple Elastic Network Interfaces (ENIs). Steps: 1. Review network interface settings. 2. Consolidate network interfaces as needed. # REF: Elastic Network Interfaces https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/using-network-interface.html

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instances should be protected by backup plan
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure a backup plan is in place for EC2 instances. Steps: 1. Review existing backup plans. 2. Implement AWS Backup for automated backups. # REF: AWS Backup / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/aws-backup/latest/devguide/whatisbackup.html

title: EC2
control_title: Public EC2 instances should have IAM profile attached
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure IAM profiles are attached to public EC2 instances. Steps: 1. Review instance configurations. 2. Attach appropriate IAM roles to instances. # REF: IAM Roles for EC2 / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_roles_use_switch-role.html

title: EC2
control_title: AWS EC2 instances should have termination protection enabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure termination protection is enabled for EC2 instances. Steps: 1. Review instance settings. 2. Enable termination protection for critical instances. # REF: Termination Protection / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_roles_use_switch-role.html

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instances user data should not have secrets
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure user data does not contain secrets. Steps: 1. Review user data scripts. 2. Remove any sensitive information. # REF: EC2 User Data / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/user-data.html

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 instances should use IMDSv2
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure IMDSv2 (Instance Metadata Service v2) is enabled for EC2 instances. Steps: 1. Review instance metadata settings. 2. Enable IMDSv2 if not already set. # REF: IMDSv2 / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ec2-instance-metadata.html

title: EC2
control_title: Paravirtual EC2 instance types should not be used
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure that only HVM (Hardware Virtual Machine) instance types are used. Steps: 1. Review instance types. 2. Migrate any paravirtual instances to HVM types. # REF: HVM vs. PV / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/virtualization.html

title: EC2
control_title: AWS EC2 launch templates should not assign public IPs to network interfaces
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure launch templates do not assign public IPs to EC2 instances. Steps: 1. Review launch template settings. 2. Update templates to avoid public IP assignments. # REF: Launch Templates /  https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/launch-templates.html

title: EC2
control_title: Ensure unused ENIs are removed
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure that unused Elastic Network Interfaces (ENIs) are deleted. Steps: 1. Review ENI configurations. 2. Delete any ENIs that are not attached to instances. # REF: Managing ENIs / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/using-network-interface.html

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 stopped instances should be removed in 30 days
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure that stopped EC2 instances are reviewed and removed after 30 days. Steps: 1. List stopped instances. 2. Terminate instances older than 30 days. # REF: Stopping and Terminating Instances https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/terminating-instances.html

title: EC2
control_title: Ensure instances stopped for over 90 days are removed
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure that EC2 instances that have been stopped for over 90 days are deleted. Steps: 1. Review stopped instances. 2. Automate deletion of instances older than 90 days. # REF: Instance Management / https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/stop-instances-90-days/

title: EC2
control_title: EC2 transit gateways should have auto accept shared attachments disabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure that EC2 transit gateways have auto-accept shared attachments disabled for security. Steps: 1. Review transit gateway settings. 2. Disable auto-accept if enabled. # REF: Transit Gateway / https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/vpc-transit-gateway.html#tg-auto-accept

title: ECR
control_title: ECR repositories should have image scan on push enabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open ECR console, select your repository, click "Edit," enable "Scan on push," and save changes. This ensures that images are automatically scanned for vulnerabilities upon upload.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECR/latest/userguide/image-scanning.html

title: ECR
control_title: ECR repositories should have lifecycle policies configured
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
open the ECR console, select your repository, navigate to the "Lifecycle policy" tab, and create a policy by defining rules for image retention. This automates the management of container images, helping to optimize storage and organization.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECR/latest/userguide/lp_creation.html

title: ECR
control_title: ECR repositories should prohibit public access
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Create a repository with the default Private visibility in the ECR console, and configure access permissions using repository policies or IAM roles. Push your container images to the repository, ensuring only authorized users or services can access them.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECR/latest/userguide/repository-create.html

title: ECR
control_title: ECR private repositories should have tag immutability configured
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open Amazon ECR private repository, go to the repository's settings in the ECR console, select Edit, and enable the Tag immutability option. This prevents image tags from being overwritten, ensuring version consistency and security.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECR/latest/userguide/image-tag-mutability.html

title: ECS
control_title: ECS clusters should have container insights enabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open ECS console and enable Container Insights in the monitoring settings of the cluster. This will allow you to monitor performance metrics like CPU, memory, and network utilization for better visibility and management of your containers.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonCloudWatch/latest/monitoring/deploy-container-insights-ECS-cluster.html

title: ECS
control_title: ECS cluster container instances should have connected agent
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Launch an instance using the Amazon ECS-Optimized AMI (which comes with the agent pre-installed) or manually install Docker, then pull and run the agent using Docker commands. Ensure your instance has the appropriate IAM role and security group settings to allow communication with the ECS service?.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECS/latest/developerguide/ecs-agent-config.html

title: ECS
control_title: ECS clusters encryption at rest should be enabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Create or select a KMS key in the AWS KMS console and configure your ECS task definition to use this key for encrypting EBS volumes. Deploy your service with the updated task definition to ensure that all data stored is encrypted at rest.
Reference: https://docs.cgn.portal.checkpoint.com/docs/d9_aws_cry_19
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECS/latest/developerguide/ebs-kms-encryption.html

title: ECS
control_title: ECS cluster instances should be in a VPC
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
To place ECS cluster instances in a VPC, launch your EC2 instances within an existing VPC by selecting the VPC and appropriate subnets during the instance setup. Ensure that security groups and network settings are configured to allow proper communication between your ECS components.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECS/latest/developerguide/get-set-up-for-amazon-ecs.html#:~:text=You%20can%20use%20Amazon%20Virtual,task%2C%20Create%20a%20security%20group.

title: ECS
control_title: ECS cluster should be configured with active services
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Navigate to the ECS console, select your cluster, and create a new service by specifying the launch type, task definition, and desired number of tasks. This allows you to manage and deploy your containerized applications effectively within the cluster.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECS/latest/developerguide/ecs_services.html

title: ECS
control_title: At least one instance should be registered with ECS cluster
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Launch an EC2 instance using an ECS-optimized AMI and specify the ECS cluster name in the user data under Advanced Details. Once launched, the instance will automatically register itself with the ECS service, enabling it to run tasks.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECS/latest/developerguide/ecs-anywhere-registration.html

title: ECS
control_title: ECS fargate services should run on the latest fargate platform version
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Navigate to the ECS console, select your cluster and service, and update the service to specify the latest platform version in the configuration. This enables your tasks to utilize the newest features and security improvements provided by AWS.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECS/latest/developerguide/platform-fargate.html

title: ECS
control_title: ECS services should be attached to a load balancer
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Navigate to the ECS console, select your cluster, and either create or update your service by enabling the Load balancer option and choosing an existing Application Load Balancer (ALB) or Network Load Balancer (NLB). Specify the target group during the configuration process and complete the creation or update to ensure traffic is distributed across your task instances.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECS/latest/developerguide/alb.html

title: ECS
control_title: AWS ECS services should not have public IP addresses assigned to them automatically
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Navigate to the ECS console, select your cluster, and either create or update your service. In the Network Configuration section, set the service to run in a private subnet and disable the Assign Public IP option.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/ecs-controls.html#:~:text=If%20you%20launch%20your%20Amazon,to%20your%20container%20application%20servers.

title: ECS
control_title: ECS task definition containers should not have secrets passed as environment variables
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Store your sensitive data in AWS Secrets Manager by creating a new secret and noting its name or ARN. Then, update your task definition in the ECS console to reference the secret in the Secrets section instead of using environment variables.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECS/latest/developerguide/specifying-sensitive-data.html

title: ECS
control_title: ECS containers should run as non-privileged
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Update your task definition in the ECS console and specify a non-root user ID or username in the User field of the container definition. This configuration minimizes security risks by limiting permissions within the container.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/config/latest/developerguide/ecs-containers-nonprivileged.html

title: ECS
control_title: ECS containers should be limited to read-only access to root filesystems
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Update your task definition in the ECS console and enable the readonlyRootfs option by setting it to true. This configuration prevents any modifications to the filesystem, enhancing the security of the container environment.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/config/latest/developerguide/ecs-containers-readonly-access.html

title: ECS
control_title: ECS task definitions should have logging enabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Update your task definition in the ECS console and create a new revision. In the container definition, select awslogs as the log driver under the Log configuration section, specifying the log group and stream prefix for Amazon CloudWatch Logs.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECS/latest/developerguide/ecs-logging-monitoring.html

title: ECS
control_title: ECS task definitions should not share the host's process namespace
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Update your task definition in the ECS console and create a new revision. Set the PID mode to task or leave it blank to prevent the container from accessing the host's processes, enhancing security.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/ecs-controls.html

title: ECS
control_title: ECS task definitions should not use root user.
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Update your task definition in the ECS console and specify a non-root user ID or username in the User field of the container definition. This enhances security by reducing the risk of privilege escalation within the container.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/config/latest/developerguide/ecs-task-definition-nonroot-user.html

title: ECS
control_title: ECS task definition container definitions should be checked for host mode
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Go to the AWS Management Console, select your ECS cluster, navigate to the Task Definitions section, and review the container definitions for the networkMode setting. If its set to host, the container will share the host's network stack, allowing for direct access to host ports?
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/config/latest/developerguide/ecs-task-definition-user-for-host-mode-check.html

title: EFS
control_title: EFS access points should enforce a root directory
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure EFS access points enforce a root directory. Steps: 1. Review EFS access point configurations. 2. Enforce a root directory for all access points to enhance security. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/efs/latest/userguide/efs-access-points.html

title: EFS
control_title: EFS access points should enforce a user identity
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure EFS access points enforce a user identity. Steps: 1. Review EFS access point settings. 2. Implement user identity enforcement for access points to restrict access based on user. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/efs/latest/userguide/efs-access-points.html

title: EFS

In the S3 Console, create or modify an access point and ensure all "Block public access" options are checked.
Open Amazon S3, select "Access Points," choose the desired access point, click "Edit" in "Public access settings," enable "Block all public access," and click "Save changes."

title: S3
control_title: S3 buckets access control lists (ACLs) should not be used to manage user access to buckets
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Remove any existing ACLs from your S3 buckets and implement IAM policies to manage user access permissions by attaching them to the relevant IAM users or roles. 
Go to the bucket's Permissions tab, edit the Access Control List (ACL), uncheck or remove all grantees, and save changes. Then, create an IAM policy under the IAM service, attach it to the relevant IAM users or roles, and manage S3 access permissions through that policy.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/reference_policies_examples_s3_rw-bucket.html

title: S3
control_title: S3 bucket cross-region replication should be enabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open the S3 Console, select the bucket, go to Management, add a replication rule, specify the destination bucket, enable versioning, and save changes.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/replication.html
COST: Depends on data transfer and storage costs

title: S3
control_title: S3 bucket default encryption should be enabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open the S3 console, select the bucket, go to Properties, enable Default Encryption, and save changes.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/UsingEncryption.html
COST: Cost: None/$0  (but KMS may incur costs)

title: S3
control_title: S3 bucket default encryption should be enabled with KMS
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
To enable default encryption with KMS for an S3 bucket, open the S3 console, select the bucket, navigate to the "Properties" tab, enable default encryption, choose "AWS Key Management Service key (SSE-KMS)," select your KMS key, and save the changes.
Reference:  https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/example-bucket-policies.html#example-bucket-policies-encryption
COST: KMS costs apply based on usage

title: S3
control_title: S3 buckets should enforce SSL
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
To enforce SSL for your S3 buckets, set a bucket policy that denies HTTP requests, allowing only HTTPS. Consider using Amazon CloudFront to require HTTPS and enable server-side encryption for added security.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/example-bucket-policies.html#example-bucket-policies-HTTP-HTTPS

title: S3
control_title: S3 buckets should have event notifications enabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Enable S3 bucket event notifications to monitor changes like object creation or deletion by configuring alerts to trigger actions in SNS, SQS, or Lambda.
Open the S3 console, select your bucket, go to the Properties tab, and under Event notifications, click Create event notification to specify events like object creation or deletion and choose a destination (SNS, SQS, or Lambda).
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/enable-event-notifications.html
COST: Cost: None/$0  (but may incur SNS costs if used)

title: S3
control_title: S3 buckets should have lifecycle policies configured
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Configure S3 lifecycle policies to transition active data to Standard-IA after 30 days, archive to Glacier after 90 days, and delete objects older than 365 days; for archival data, move to Glacier after 90 days and delete after 7 years; for temporary files, delete after 7 days.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/lifecycle-configuration-examples.html

title: S3
control_title: S3 bucket logging should be enabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
To enable S3 bucket logging and track access requests, go to the S3 console, select your bucket, click on "Properties," under "Server access logging," enable it, and specify a target bucket to store the logs for analysis.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/enable-server-access-logging.html

title: S3
control_title: Ensure MFA Delete is enabled on S3 buckets
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Enable versioning on your S3 bucket through the AWS Management Console, CLI, or SDKs. Then, set up MFA for your IAM user and configure MFA Delete using the AWS CLI or SDKs, as it cannot be done via the Management Console.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/MultiFactorAuthenticationDelete.html

title: S3
control_title: S3 bucket ACLs should not be accessible to all authenticated user
Recommendation Steps/Approach: To restrict S3 bucket ACLs from being accessible to all authenticated users, remove any permissions for "Authenticated Users" in the ACL settings and review the bucket policy to ensure no access is granted to this group. Consider using bucket policies for more granular control instead of ACLs.reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/walkthrough1.html

title: S3
control_title: S3 bucket object lock should be enabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
while reating a new bucket and select Enable Object Lock during the setup, choosing the desired retention period and mode. Object Lock cannot be added to existing buckets, so you'll need to migrate objects to a newly created bucket with this feature.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/object-lock-configure.html
COST: Cost: None/$0  (but may incur storage costs)

title: S3
control_title: S3 buckets object logging should be enabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
To enable object logging for an S3 bucket, go to the bucket in the S3 console, navigate to the Properties tab, and enable Server Access Logging by specifying a target bucket for logs. This will capture and store logs of all requests made to the bucket.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/enable-server-access-logging.html

title: S3
control_title: S3 bucket policy should prohibit public access
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
To prohibit public access to an S3 bucket, create a bucket policy that denies access to any principal (user or account) except for specific allowed users.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/access-control-block-public-access.html

title: S3
control_title: AWS S3 permissions granted to other AWS accounts in bucket policies should be restricted
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open bucket polacies, Review Current Policies and Restrict access only to trusted AWS accounts.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/access-grants-cross-accounts.html

title: S3
control_title: S3 buckets should prohibit public read access
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
To prohibit public read access to an S3 bucket, enable all options under the Block public access settings in the bucket's Permissions tab. Additionally, review the bucket policy for any statements allowing public read access and remove or modify them as necessary.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/config/latest/developerguide/s3-bucket-public-read-prohibited.html

title: S3
control_title: S3 buckets should prohibit public write access
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Access the S3 console, select the bucket, enable all options under Block public access in the Permissions tab, and review the bucket policy to modify or remove any public write access statements as needed.
reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/config/latest/developerguide/s3-bucket-public-write-prohibited.html

title: S3
control_title: S3 buckets static website hosting should be disabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Go to the AWS S3 console, select the desired bucket, and navigate to the "Properties" tab. Scroll down to the "Static website hosting" section, click "Edit," select "Disable," and save the changes.

title: S3
control_title: S3 buckets with versioning enabled should have lifecycle policies configured
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Go to the S3 console, select the bucket, and navigate to the "Management" tab to create a lifecycle rule. Define transitions or expirations for non-current versions, then review and save the rule.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/how-to-set-lifecycle-configuration-intro.html

title: S3
control_title: S3 bucket versioning should be enabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Go to the AWS S3 console, select the bucket, and navigate to the "Properties" tab. In the "Bucket Versioning" section, click "Edit," enable versioning, and save the changes.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/Versioning.html
COST: Cost: None/$0  (but may incur storage costs)

title: S3
control_title: S3 public access should be blocked at account level
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Ggo to the AWS Management Console, open the S3 service, and click on "Block Public Access settings for this account." Then, enable the block for all public access settings, including new and existing buckets, and save the changes to apply account-wide.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/config/latest/developerguide/s3-account-level-public-access-blocks.html

title: S3
control_title: S3 public access should be blocked at bucket levels
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Go to the AWS S3 console, select the bucket, and navigate to the "Permissions" tab. Under the "Block public access" section, click "Edit," enable all block options, and save the changes.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/configuring-block-public-access-bucket.html

title: S3
control_title: S3 public access should be blocked at account and bucket levels
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Go to the AWS S3 console and navigate to "Block Public Access settings for this account" under the "S3" dashboard. Enable all options to block public access at the account level. Then, for each bucket, go to the "Permissions" tab, edit the "Block public access" settings, enable all options, and save the changes.

Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure VPC flow logs are enabled. Steps: 1. Review VPC settings. 2. Enable flow logs for all VPCs. # REF:VPC Flow Logs :https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/flow-logs.html

title: Security
control_title: Ensure a support role has been created to manage incidents with AWS Support
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure a support role has been created to manage incidents with AWS Support. Steps: 1. Check IAM roles. 2. Create a support role if not present. # REF:AWS Support Role :https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/aws_support_roles.html

title: Security
control_title: ECR repositories should have image scan on push enabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure ECR repositories have image scan on push enabled. Steps: 1. Review ECR repository settings. 2. Enable image scanning on push if not already enabled. # REF:ECR Image Scanning :https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECR/latest/userguide/image-scanning.html

title: Security Hub
control_title: AWS Security Hub should be enabled for an AWS Account
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure AWS Security Hub is enabled for an AWS account. Steps: 1. Go to the Security Hub console. 2. Enable Security Hub for the account. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/securityhub-setup.html

title: SNS
control_title: SNS topics should be encrypted at rest
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure SNS topics are encrypted at rest. Steps: 1. Review SNS topic settings. 2. Enable encryption for topics if not already enabled. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sns/latest/dg/sns-server-side-encryption.html

title: SNS
control_title: Logging of delivery status should be enabled for notification messages sent to a topic
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure logging of delivery status is enabled for SNS topics. Steps: 1. Review SNS topic settings. 2. Enable delivery status logging if not already enabled. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sns/latest/dg/sns-message-delivery-retries.html

title: SNS
control_title: SNS topic policies should prohibit cross account access
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure SNS topic policies prohibit cross-account access. Steps: 1. Review SNS topic policies. 2. Modify policies to restrict cross-account access. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sns/latest/dg/sns-policy-forms.html

title: SNS
control_title: SNS topic policies should prohibit public access
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure SNS topic policies prohibit public access. Steps: 1. Review SNS topic policies. 2. Modify policies to restrict public access. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sns/latest/dg/sns-policy-forms.html

title: SNS
control_title: SNS topic policies should prohibit publishing access
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure SNS topic policies prohibit unauthorized publishing access. Steps: 1. Review SNS topic policies. 2. Modify policies to restrict publishing access. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sns/latest/dg/sns-policy-forms.html

title: SNS
control_title: SNS topic policies should prohibit subscription public access
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure SNS topic policies prohibit public subscription access. Steps: 1. Review SNS topic policies. 2. Modify policies to restrict subscription access. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sns/latest/dg/sns-policy-forms.html

title: SQS
control_title: SQS queues should be configured with a dead-letter queue.
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure SQS queues are configured with a dead-letter queue. Steps: 1. Review SQS queue settings. 2. Configure a dead-letter queue for each SQS queue. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/sqs-configure-dead-letter-queues.html

title: SQS
control_title: AWS SQS queues should be encrypted at rest
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure AWS SQS queues are encrypted at rest. Steps: 1. Review SQS queue settings. 2. Enable server-side encryption if not already done. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/sqs-server-side-encryption.html

title: SQS
control_title: SQS queues should be encrypted with KMS CMK
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure SQS queues are encrypted with KMS CMK. Steps: 1. Review SQS queue settings. 2. Enable KMS encryption for each queue. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/sqs-server-side-encryption-KMS.html

title: SQS
control_title: SQS queue policies should prohibit public access
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure SQS queue policies prohibit public access. Steps: 1. Review SQS queue policies. 2. Modify policies to restrict public access. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/sqs-policy-forms.html

title: SSM
control_title: EC2 instances should be managed by AWS Systems Manager
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure EC2 instances are managed by AWS Systems Manager. Steps: 1. Verify that EC2 instances are registered with Systems Manager. 2. Install SSM agent if not already present. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/systems-manager/latest/userguide/ssm-agent.html

title: SSM
control_title: SSM documents should not be public
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure SSM documents are not public. Steps: 1. Review SSM document permissions. 2. Restrict permissions to prevent public access. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/systems-manager/latest/userguide/documents-access.html

title: SSM
control_title: SSM managed instance associations should be compliant
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure SSM managed instance associations are compliant. Steps: 1. Review association status for managed instances. 2. Resolve any non-compliant associations. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/systems-manager/latest/userguide/managed-instance.html

title: SSM
control_title: SSM managed instance patching should be compliant
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure SSM managed instance patching is compliant. Steps: 1. Review the patch compliance status of managed instances. 2. Configure patching baselines and ensure compliance with patching requirements. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/systems-manager/latest/userguide/patch-manager.html

title: SSM
control_title: SSM parameters encryption should be enabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure SSM parameters encryption is enabled. Steps: 1. Review parameter store settings. 2. Enable encryption for sensitive parameters using KMS. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/systems-manager/latest/userguide/systems-manager-parameter-store.html

title: Step Functions
control_title: Step Functions state machines should have logging turned on
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Step Functions state machines should have logging turned on: 1. Access the AWS Step Functions console. 2. Select the state machine to edit. 3. In the settings, enable CloudWatch logging to capture execution details. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/step-functions/latest/dg/cloudwatch-logging.html

title: VPC
control_title: VPC should be configured to use VPC endpoints
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open the VPC console, choose either a Gateway or Interface endpoint, select the desired service, configure the VPC and route tables or subnets, adjust security groups, and test connectivity
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/codecatalyst/latest/adminguide/managing-vpcs.endpoint.html

title: VPC
control_title: VPC default security group should not allow inbound and outbound traffic
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
open the VPC console, select the default security group, edit both inbound and outbound rules to remove all existing rules, and save the changes or create a new secuirirty group.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/creating-security-groups.html

title: VPC
control_title: VPC EIPs should be associated with an EC2 instance or ENI
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open the EC2 console, select the Elastic IP, choose to associate it with either an instance or an ENI, and complete the association.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/managing-network-interface-ip-addresses.html

title: VPC
control_title: VPC endpoint services should have acceptance required enabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open the VPC console, navigate to Endpoint Services, create or modify a service, check the "Require acceptance" option, and save the changes.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/privatelink/configure-endpoint-service.html

title: VPC
control_title: VPC flow logs should be enabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open the VPC console, select your VPC, choose Create flow log from the actions menu, configure the settings for traffic filtering and log destination, and then create the flow log.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/config/latest/developerguide/vpc-flow-logs-enabled.html
COST: Costs may apply (based on log storage and data transfer)

title: VPC
control_title: VPC gateway endpoints should restrict public access
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open the VPC console, select the endpoint, edit the endpoint policy to define access restrictions, and save the changes.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/privatelink/vpc-endpoints-access.html

title: VPC
control_title: VPC internet gateways should be attached to authorized vpc
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open the VPC console, verify the attachments of existing internet gateways, attach them to authorized VPCs as needed, and detach any from unauthorized VPCs.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/config/latest/developerguide/internet-gateway-authorized-vpc-only.html

title: VPC
control_title: VPCs should exist in multiple regions
Recommendation Steps/Approach: VPCs should exist in multiple regions: 1. Review your current VPC configurations to ensure that you have VPCs deployed across multiple regions. 2. If not, create additional VPCs in other regions as needed for redundancy and availability. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/what-is-amazon-vpc.html

title: VPC
control_title: Network ACLs should not allow ingress from 0.0.0.0/0 to port 22 or port 3389
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Restrict traffic from anywhere (both IPv4: 0.0.0.0/0 and IPv6: ::/0) and allow only from specific IP addresses and port numbers
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/vpc-security-groups.html; https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/vpc-security-groups.html

title: VPC
control_title: VPC network access control lists (network ACLs) should be associated with a subnet.
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Create a Network ACL in the VPC Dashboard, define inbound/outbound rules to allow/deny specific IPs and ports. Then, associate the ACL with your desired subnets under Subnet Associations to apply the rules.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/vpc-network-acls.html

title: VPC
control_title: VPCs should be in use
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Schedule periodic checks to identify any new unused VPCs

title: VPC
control_title: VPCs peering connection should not be allowed in cross account
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
To disallow VPC peering connections across AWS accounts, ensure that you do not create or accept any peering requests between VPCs in different accounts, implement strict IAM policies that restrict permissions for VPC peering actions, use service control policies (SCPs) in AWS Organizations to deny VPC peering actions across accounts, and regularly audit your VPC settings to identify any unauthorized peering connections.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/peering/vpc-peering-basics.html#:~:text=You%20cannot%20create%20a%20VPC,or%20only%20IPv6%20CIDR%20blocks.

title: VPC
control_title: VPCs peering connection route tables should have least privilege
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open the AWS Management Console, navigate to the VPC Dashboard, and select Route Tables to ensure private subnets do not have routes directing traffic to the Internet Gateway (IGW), while public subnets should have a route for 0.0.0.0/0 to the IGW. Then, configure security groups and network ACLs for private subnets to deny unwanted inbound traffic from the Internet and verify the subnet CIDR blocks for proper access restrictions.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/VPC_Route_Tables.html

title: VPC
control_title: VPC route table should restrict public access to IGW
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
To restrict public access, remove any route in the VPC route table pointing to the Internet Gateway (IGW) with 0.0.0.0/0 (IPv4) or ::/0 (IPv6). Then, add necessary private routes for internal access, such as via a NAT Gateway, and verify that no public routes remain.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/route-table-options.html

title: VPC
control_title: VPC Security groups should only allow unrestricted incoming traffic for authorized ports
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
To secure your VPC, review security groups and restrict unrestricted incoming traffic (0.0.0.0/0 or ::/0) to only authorized ports, such as 80 (HTTP) and 443 (HTTPS). Ensure all other ports are either closed or limited to specific IP addresses or private subnets for access control.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/security-group-rules.html

title: VPC
control_title: VPC security groups should restrict ingress from 0.0.0.0/0 or ::/0 to cassandra ports 7199 or 9160 or 8888
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Restrict traffic from anywhere (both IPv4: 0.0.0.0/0 and IPv6: ::/0) and allow only from specific IP addresses
Open EC2 dashboard and select "Security Groups." Review the inbound rules for each security group and remove any rules allowing access to these ports from 0.0.0.0/0 or ::/0, replacing them with more specific IP addresses or CIDR blocks that require access.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/ec2-controls.html

Review the inbound rules for each security group and remove any rules allowing access to port 11211 from 0.0.0.0/0 or ::/0, replacing them with more specific IP addresses or CIDR blocks that require access.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/ec2-controls.html

Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/ec2-controls.html

Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/ec2-controls.html

title: VPC
control_title: VPC security groups should be associated with at least one ENI
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open EC2 dashboard and select "Security Groups." For each security group, check the associated resources, and ensure that at least one ENI is attached. If a security group is not associated with any ENI, either delete the group or associate it with an active ENI.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/config/latest/developerguide/ec2-security-group-attached-to-eni.html

title: VPC
control_title: VPC security groups should restrict uses of 'launch-wizard' security groups.
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open EC2 dashboard and select "Security Groups." Search for any security groups named 'launch-wizard' and review their usage. Modify or replace them with properly configured security groups that follow best practices, or delete them if they are no longer in use.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/launchwizard/latest/userguide/best-practices.html#security-groups

title: VPC
control_title: Ensure no security groups allow ingress from 0.0.0.0/0 to remote server administration ports
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open EC2 dashboard and select "Security Groups." Review each security group's inbound rules and remove any rules that permit ingress traffic on remote administration ports from 0.0.0.0/0, replacing them with more specific IP addresses or CIDR ranges that require access.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/ec2-controls.html

title: VPC
control_title: Ensure no security groups allow ingress from ::/0 to remote server administration ports
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open EC2 dashboard and select "Security Groups." Review each security groups inbound rules and remove any rules that permit ingress traffic on remote administration ports from ::/0, replacing them with more specific IPv6 addresses or CIDR ranges that require access.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/ec2-controls.html

title: VPC
control_title: Ensure no security groups allow ingress from 0.0.0.0/0 to remote server administration ports
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open EC2 dashboard and select "Security Groups." Review each security groups inbound rules and remove any rules that permit ingress traffic from 0.0.0.0/0 for these ports, replacing them with more specific IP addresses or CIDR ranges that need access.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/security-group-rules-reference.html

title: VPC
control_title: VPC security groups should restrict ingress Kafka port access from 0.0.0.0/0
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open EC2 dashboard and select "Security Groups." Choose the relevant security group, review the inbound rules, and remove any rules that allow access to port 9092 from 0.0.0.0/0, replacing them with more specific IP addresses or CIDR ranges that require Kafka access.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/security-group-rules-reference.html

title: VPC
control_title: VPC security groups should restrict ingress kibana port access from 0.0.0.0/0
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open EC2 dashboard and select "Security Groups." Choose the relevant security group, review the inbound rules, and remove any rules that allow access to port 5601 from 0.0.0.0/0, replacing them with more specific IP addresses or CIDR blocks that need access to Kibana.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/ec2-controls.html

title: VPC
control_title: Ensure no security groups allow ingress from 0.0.0.0/0 to port 3389
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open EC2 dashboard and select "Security Groups." Review each security groups inbound rules, and remove any rules that permit ingress traffic on port 3389 from 0.0.0.0/0, replacing them with more specific IP addresses or ranges that require RDP access.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/ec2-controls.html

title: VPC
control_title: VPC security groups should restrict ingress redis access from 0.0.0.0/0
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open the EC2 dashboard and select "Security Groups." Review the inbound rules for each security group and remove any rules allowing access to Redis (port 6379) from 0.0.0.0/0, replacing them with more specific IP addresses or CIDR blocks that require access.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/ec2-controls.html

title: VPC
control_title: VPC security groups should restrict ingress SSH access from 0.0.0.0/0
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open the EC2 dashboard and select "Security Groups." Review the inbound rules for each security group and remove any rules allowing SSH access (port 22) from 0.0.0.0/0, replacing them with specific IP addresses or CIDR ranges.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/ec2-controls.html

title: VPC
control_title: VPC security groups should restrict ingress TCP and UDP access from 0.0.0.0/0
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open the EC2 dashboard and select "Security Groups." Review the inbound rules for each security group and remove any rules allowing unrestricted TCP or UDP access from 0.0.0.0/0, replacing them with more specific IP addresses or CIDR blocks that require access.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/ec2-controls.html

title: VPC
control_title: Security groups should not allow unrestricted access to ports with high risk
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open EC2 dashboard and select "Security Groups." Review the inbound rules for each security group and remove any rules that permit ingress traffic from ::/0 for these ports, replacing them with more specific IPv6 addresses or CIDR ranges that require access.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/security-group-rules-reference.html

title: VPC
control_title: Unused EC2 security groups should be removed
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open AWS Console, navigate to the EC2 dashboard and select "Security Groups" from the sidebar. Identify security groups not associated with any EC2 instances, then select the unused groups and click on the "Actions" dropdown to choose "Delete security groups" to remove them.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/systems-manager-automation-runbooks/latest/userguide/automation-aws-delete-ec2-security-group.html

title: VPC
control_title: VPC subnet auto assign public IP should be disabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open  AWS Console, navigate to the VPC dashboard, select "Subnets," and choose the subnet you want to modify. Click on the "Actions" dropdown, select "Edit auto-assign IP settings," and uncheck the "Auto-assign public IPv4 address" option, then save your changes.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/config/latest/developerguide/subnet-auto-assign-public-ip-disabled.html#:~:text=Checks%20if%20Amazon%20Virtual%20Private,assigned%20a%20public%20IP%20address.

title: VPC
control_title: VPCs subnets should exist in multiple availability zones
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open VPC dashboard, select your VPC, and choose "Subnets," then click "Create subnet." Specify the subnet details, including the Availability Zone, CIDR block, and any tags, ensuring to repeat this for each zone you want to include.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/create-subnets.html

title: VPC
control_title: VPCs should have both public and private subnets configured
Recommendation Steps/Approach: To configure both public and private subnets in a VPC using the AWS Console, create subnets within your VPC and associate a route table with an Internet Gateway (IGW) for the public subnets. For private subnets, configure a route table with a NAT Gateway to allow outbound internet access while keeping them inaccessible from the public internet. Reference:https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/configure-subnets.html

title: VPC
control_title: Both VPN tunnels provided by AWS Site-to-Site
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
To configure both VPN tunnels provided by AWS Site-to-Site, ensure each tunnel is properly set up with the customer gateway device using the configuration file provided by AWS. Monitor the tunnels' status and configure failover settings to automatically switch between tunnels in case one goes down.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpn/latest/s2svpn/VPNTunnels.html#:~:text=You%20use%20a%20Site%2Dto,configure%20both%20tunnels%20for%20redundancy.
COST: Costs may apply (based on data transfer and connection hours)

title: WAF
control_title: WAF regional rule should have at least one condition
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Navigate to the AWS WAF Console, select your web ACL, and choose Rules to add a new rule. In the rule configuration, define at least one condition using options such as IP sets, string matches, or rate-based rules to specify how requests should be evaluated?.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/waf-controls.html#waf-2

title: WAF
control_title: WAF regional rule group should have at least one rule attached
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open AWS WAF Console, select Rule Groups, and edit your desired rule group to attach at least one rule. This attachment allows the group to effectively filter traffic based on the conditions defined in the associated rules?.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/waf-controls.html#waf-3

title: WAF
control_title: WAF regional web ACL should have at least one rule or rule group attached
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open AWS WAF Console, select your Web ACL, and attach at least one rule or rule group. This attachment allows the web ACL to evaluate and filter traffic based on the defined conditions.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/waf-controls.html#waf-4

title: WAF
control_title: WAF global rule should have at least one condition
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Open AWS WAF Console, select your rule and add the required condition to evaluate incoming requests?.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/waf-controls.html#waf-6

title: WAF
control_title: WAF global rule group should have at least one rule
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Go to the AWS WAF console, select "Web ACLs," and choose your Web ACL.
Under "Rules," select "Add rules" and choose a global rule group, then configure at least one rule within the group.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/waf-controls.html#waf-7

title: WAF
control_title: WAF web ACL logging should be enabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
In the AWS WAF console, select "Web ACLs," choose your Web ACL, and click "Edit."
Under "Logging," enable logging by selecting an S3 bucket, CloudWatch Logs, or Kinesis Firehose. 
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/waf/latest/developerguide/logging.html

title: WAF
control_title: WAF global web ACL should have at least one rule or rule group
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Create a Web ACL in AWS WAF and add a rule or rule group under "Rules" during setup.
Assign this Web ACL to your CloudFront distribution or AWS resources (e.g., API Gateway or ALB).
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/waf-controls.html#waf-10

title: WAFv2
control_title: AWS WAF rules should have CloudWatch metrics enabled
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Navigate to AWS WAF, select your Web ACL, and ensure logging is enabled in the "Logging and Metrics" section. Each rule in the Web ACL automatically generates CloudWatch metrics, visible in CloudWatch under the AWS/WAFV2 namespace. 
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/waf-controls.html#waf-12

title: WAFv2
control_title: Logging should be enabled on AWS WAFv2 regional and global web access control list (ACLs)
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Go to AWS WAF in the AWS Management Console, select your Web ACL (regional or global). In the Logging and metrics tab, enable logging and choose an Amazon S3 bucket, Kinesis Data Firehose, or CloudWatch Logs as the destination for log storage.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/config/latest/developerguide/wafv2-logging-enabled.html

title: WAFv2
control_title: A WAFV2 web ACL should have at least one rule or rule group
Recommendation Steps/Approach:
Create a Web ACL: In the AWS Management Console, navigate to AWS WAF, and create a new Web ACL. Add Rules or Rule Groups: During the setup process, add at least one rule or rule group to the Web ACL under the "Rules" section to meet compliance requirements.
Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/config/latest/developerguide/wafv2-webacl-not-empty.html

control_title: Ensure inline policies attached to IAM users, roles, and groups should not allow blocked actions on KMS keys
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure inline policies attached to IAM users, roles, and groups should not allow blocked actions on KMS keys: 1. Audit inline policies for IAM users, roles, and groups. 2. Remove or modify any policies that allow blocked actions on KMS keys. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/access_policies.html

title: ELB
control_title: ELB application, network, and gateway load balancers should span multiple availability zones
Recommendation Steps/Approach: ELB application, network, and gateway load balancers should span multiple availability zones: 1. Review your ELB configurations to ensure they are deployed across multiple availability zones. 2. Modify the settings as necessary to achieve high availability. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/elasticloadbalancing/latest/userguide/create-load-balancer.html

title: S3
control_title: Ensure all data in AWS S3 has been discovered, classified, and secured when required
Recommendation Steps/Approach: Ensure all data in AWS S3 has been discovered, classified, and secured when required: 1. Implement AWS tools to discover and classify data in S3. 2. Apply security measures as needed based on the classification. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/UsingObjects.html

title: ACM
control_title: RSA certificates managed by ACM should use a key length of at least 2,048 bits
Recommendation Steps/Approach: RSA certificates managed by ACM should use a key length of at least 2,048 bits: 1. Audit your ACM certificates to check the key length. 2. Replace any certificates with a key length less than 2,048 bits. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/acm/latest/userguide/acm-certificate.html

title: IAM
control_title: IAM groups, users, and roles should not have any inline policies
Recommendation Steps/Approach: IAM groups, users, and roles should not have any inline policies: 1. Review the IAM configurations for groups, users, and roles. 2. Replace inline policies with managed policies where possible. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/access_policies.html
